It‚Äôs a huge tax cut for the wealthy at the expense of older and lower-income Americans, who will face increased costs and other barriers to care. It‚Äôs unthinkable that the House will consider passing a bill that not only drops 14 million Americans from coverage immediately, but could increase premiums by 20 percent. The Republican health care plan will result in devastating losses in coverage ‚Äì up to 24 million more uninsured by 2026 according to recent Congressional Budget Office (CBO) analysis. What‚Äôs worse is that this plan is paid for on the backs of seniors and older Americans, who will see a dramatic increase in costs which could put insurance out of reach for many. Under the ACA, a 64-year old making $26,500 would pay $1,700 in premiums in 2026, but under the GOP plan, the same person would pay $14,600 ‚Äì an astonishing spike of more than 750%.  Thanks to the ACA, older Americans have better access to quality care, but these gains will be lost under the GOP plan which costs Americans more, and offers them less. In particular, this plan harms older Mainers by:                            Charging more for premiums ‚Äì The Republican plan increases the amount that insurance companies can charge 50-64 year olds up to 5 times more. While current law does allow for ‚Äúage rating‚Äù of 3:1, AARP estimates that increasing this to 5:1 could result in premium spikes of up to $3,200 for a 64 year old.                                                                                Rolling back Medicaid ‚Äì Not only does the Republican plan put an end to state Medicaid expansion opportunities, it sets a limit on the federal contribution for each enrollee. These arbitrary ‚Äúper capita caps‚Äù mean that states won‚Äôt be able to increase coverage when populations increase, or to add new benefits, or to increase payments to providers when needed.  This approach is a dramatic cost shift to states, where budgets are already constrained, and will result in drastic cuts for older Americans who are low-income, disabled, or needing long term care.   Depleting the Medicare Trust Fund ‚Äì The ACA helped to extend the life of the Medicare Part A (hospital coverage) Trust Fund. The Republican plan includes a number of tax breaks for the wealthy, including a $117 billion cut that will potentially reduce the life of the Trust Fund by 2 to 4 years.   Since the enactment of the ACA, the number of uninsured American ages 50-64 has dropped by half.  Of the 85,000 Mainers enrolled on the Health Insurance Marketplace, a full third are in the 50s and 60s. And of course, a vast number of older Mainers depend on Medicare and Medicaid for their health care. All of this is threatened by the Republican health care plan that appears to be nothing more than a shameful attempt to keep a campaign promise. Older Americans have and continue to give us so much; they deserve greater certainty in knowing that we will protect quality, affordable health care for when they need it most. It is urgent that we bring needed security to the health care market and to the consumers whose access to care is on the line.

With so much bad news circulating this week, I wanted to celebrate the signing of the Forever GI Bill, which expands educational assistance benefits to veterans who had been denied because of technicalities. The Forever GI Bill is similar to The Chris Kotch Act, which I introduced in the previous two Congresses and named after a Purple Heart recipient from Brunswick, Maine who was denied his full GI benefits because of a loophole.   A member of the Army Reserve, Chris Kotch served on active duty for five months in Iraq before being seriously injured by an IED in 2003. He was sent to Walter Reed Hospital but was not officially discharged until he reported back to his Reserve unit.  While Kotch was medically retired as a result of his combat injuries‚Äîwhich should have made him eligible for the full benefit‚Äîhis discharge paperwork says he simply finished his active duty obligation.   Because of that wording‚Äîbecause Chris was temporarily transferred from active duty service back to the Reserves before being discharged‚Äîthe Department of Veterans Affairs said Chris wasn‚Äôt eligible for the full benefit and instead would only receive a portion.  Chris, who recently graduated with a master‚Äôs in social work, told me, "It was a pretty discouraging and degrading experience to have to fight for a benefit that should have been a given; to call agency after agency only to be told that there was nothing they could do. The issue didn‚Äôt stop me from pursuing my education, but it did mean that I had to take out loans when I shouldn‚Äôt have had to. I appreciate that veterans in my kind of situation will no longer have to fight for their education.‚Äù    Signed into law earlier this week, The Harry W. Colmery Veterans Educational Assistance Act of 2017, also called the Forever GI Bill, made a change to allow those who have been awarded the Purple Heart for service occurring on or after September 11, 2001, to access the Post-9/11 GI Bill Educational Assistance Program. I cosponsored a bill introduced by Representative Scott Peters to make this change, which was included in the final bill.   Read more about The Chris Kotch Act here: https://pingree.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/pingree-introduces-legislation-fix-loophole-gi-bill

During my time in Congress, I've been contacted by many veteran constituents who‚Äôve been surprised to find out that they owe the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) money for overpayment of benefits.   Often, these veterans only learn about the debt when their benefits are withheld.  Having never received a prior notification, they miss deadlines for appealing the debt, setting up a payment plan, or applying for a waiver. The shock of learning that they owe money when they can no longer do anything to address it adds undue stress to veterans who may be dealing with service-connected disabilities and challenges, such as homelessness.  Even when some veterans have sent a timely response, the VA has said they did not receive it. One reason is that the VA does not send notifications via certified mail, meaning that it can‚Äôt confirm whether they have a veteran‚Äôs correct address and a veteran can‚Äôt be sure of whether their response was received.   My bill, H.R. 3705, the Veterans Fair Debt Notice Act, would do two things to remedy the situation‚Äîrequiring the VA to 1) used certified mail for these kinds of notification and 2) use plain language so veterans can clearly understands their rights in these situations.   My bill has its first hearing this morning. Learn more about Mainers who will benefit from this bill via the Maine Public story below.

This morning I testified at a Congressional hearing about legislation I've introduced to help veterans who find themselves owing the Department of Veterans Affairs money. Many of these veterans never receive notifications of the debt until they realize their benefits are being withheld because the VA has the wrong address. Since they get lost in the mail, veterans miss their deadline for taking action, whether that's appealing the debt, applying for an exemption, or setting up a payment plan.   My bill, the Veterans Fair Debt Notice Act, would require the VA to send these notifications via certified mail to ensure that they are received, and to write them in plain language so veterans clearly understand their options. Getting lost in the mail should be no excuse for putting our veterans under this kind of unnecessary, undue stress.

#BREAKING: The House Committee on Veterans' Affairs has passed an amended version of H.R. 3705, The Veterans Fair Debt Notice Act. I filed H.R. 3705 after assisting veteran constituents who only learned about their debt with the VA once their benefits had been withheld or loans rejected. Today‚Äôs vote is an important first step in addressing this problem, giving clear and timely information to veterans about their rights and steps they can take to resolve their debt. I‚Äôm pleased that this bipartisan effort will move forward.  As amended by the committee, The Veterans Fair Debt Notice Act would:  * Direct the VA to work with veterans service organizations to come up with a standard letter with plain language to explain why the veteran owes the debt and what his/or her options are to challenge or seek forgiveness or a payment plan.   * Directs the VA to develop a method of informing veterans of the option of receiving such notices by electronic means in addition to standard mail.  * Require the VA to perform a study on (a) the scope of the problem of veterans not receiving notices in the mail, (b) steps the VA can take to improve its address database, and (c) the cost estimate of sending notifications by certified mail.
